description.narrative: Promoting Renewable Energy in Mae Hong Son Province
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - power generation
Project Objective: To overcome barriers to the provision of Renewable Energy (RE) services in integrated provincial renewable energy programmes in Thailand
Increase of power generation capacity and usage from RE systems in MHS

comment.narrative: RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 17 MW (on grid) and 2.4 MW (off-grid)
By the end of the project RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 27.06 MW (on grid) and more than 2.4 MW (off-grid). This is equivalent to an increase of at least 55,000 MWh/year)
RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 29,220 MW (on grid) and 255 kW (off-grid). (June 2015)

description.narrative: Percentage of power generation capacity nationally from RE systems

comment.narrative: 1.45% grid power generation and 5.37% grid + off-grid power generation is by RE
By the end of the project the proportion of power generation from installed or planned RE systems nationally is 6% (grid) and 8% (grid + off-grid)

description.narrative: Models for RE generation & application which can be replicated in other areas demonstrated

comment.narrative: No new models for RE generation & application.
At least 3 new models for RE generation & application developed and operational. Models ready to be replicated in other areas (hydro, solar and biodigesters)

Several models related to RE generation & application, service delivery, fund management and sustainable utilization of RE were sketched out but not finalized. For instance policy support for RE applications & energy access in forest reserved area; facilitation to local government in RE technologies, operation & maintenance (O&M); community management for productive uses of RE technologies; women empowerment in ICS realization and promotion; RE revolving fund (Clean Energy Fund) for income generation and livelihoods improvement for the marginalized groups.

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Strengthened institutional, organizational and social capacity results in planning, management and implementation of integrated RE programmes in MHS, Chiang Rai, Chiang Mai and Tak
No. of working RE management models established

comment.narrative: None
At least 3 management models established (off-grid hydro, biodigesters, solar)

A management structure for off grid microhydro power was established. The agreed structure includes responsibilities of provincial and local concerned agencies and was agreed with the participation of local communities.

description.narrative: No. of RE projects proposed by government agencies in line with provincial plan

comment.narrative: None
At least 2 RE projects proposed by government agencies in line with provincial plan

3 RE (micro-hydro power) projects were proposed and developed by 3 local governments (Tambon Administrative Organizations or TAOs), in line with local and provincial plans. TAOs will be the owner of the plants. (Completed)

description.narrative: Outcome 2: Financially sustainable RE systems operational in MHS, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai and Tak
Increase in invested amount for RE in MHS (all sectors)

comment.narrative: Investment in 2007 = 486 million baht (figure for MHS province)
By the end of the project at least an additional 800 million baht[2] is invested in RE systems in MHS compared to the baseline

description.narrative: Amounts available in the form of micro-credit for communities wishing to establish RE systems

comment.narrative: No micro-credit available
By the end of 2015 at least 10 million baht is available in the form of micro-credit to individual villages for installation of RE systems

description.narrative: Village revenues from grid-connected RE systems

comment.narrative: No income
By the end of the project village-level revenues from sale of electricity in grid-connected systems amounts to at least 15 million baht per year[3]

3 (total 2,880 kW- June 2014) 0 0
33 (at SMEs/hh June 2014)

1 additional on-grid solar farm project approved, installed and operational in MHS by end of 2016 (capacity 500 kW).
100 SHS rehabilitated in MHS by end of 2016 (100*120 Wp)
200 solar lanterns sold in MHS by end of 2016 (200*2.5W)
20 additional biodigesters at schools, SMEs and farms installed and operational in MHS by end of 2016 with support from project (average size 8 m3)
2 off-grid hydropower plants approved, installed and operational in MHS by end of 2016 (2 * 30 kW). 10 solar rooftop systems approved, installed and operational in MHS by end of 2016 (with support from the project) (10 * 200 W)
1 EE project in gov. building approved, implemented and operational in MHS by end of 2016 (RE capacity 600 W savings)
10 villages in which ICS have been tried out and being used in MHS by end of 2016 (50 systems)

2 potential locations for on-grid solar farms were selected and under land legal review. 0 2 solar lanterns demo models were selected and tried-out to find the most suitable one for MHS off-grid poverty stricken areas, in term of technology application and affordability. 3 potential locations for biodigesters at schools and another 9 at farms were identified and assessed. 3 off-grid micro-hydro power projects were approved by MHS province. 2 out of 3 projects are under investigation of land use permit by MNRE. 0 0 14 villages of 3 ethnic groups (Tai Yai, Karen, Lanna), located in peri-urban and rural areas, in which 55 ICS have been tried out and are being used.
(Completed)

description.narrative: Outcome 3: Technical support is available locally for the development, management and maintenance of RE applications in MHS, Chiang Rai, Chiang Mai and Tak
No. of village technicians trained to operate and maintain off-grid hydropower plants

comment.narrative: No knowledge or expertise centre easily available;
4 village technicians trained to operate and maintain off-grid hydropower plant by end of 2016

description.narrative: No. of village technicians trained to maintain rehabilitated SHS

comment.narrative: No knowledge (centre) or experts easily available
10 village technicians trained to maintain rehabilitated SHS by end of 2016

description.narrative: No. of technicians trained on EE measures and solar rooftop installation

comment.narrative: No knowledge (centre) or experts easily available
2 government technicians trained on EE measures and solar rooftop installation

description.narrative: No. of users trained in the operation and maintenance of biodigesters

comment.narrative: No knowledge (centre) or experts easily available
20 users of biodigesters trained to operate and maintain the systems

description.narrative: An improved design of an ICS suitable for situation in MHS

comment.narrative: No knowledge (centre) or experts easily available
Improved design for ICS suitable for MHS finalized
Improved design for ICS suitable for MHS finalized and being used among 55 project volunteers. (Completed)

description.narrative: Outcome 4: Policies facilitate up-scaling and replication of RE systems in Thailand

Documented and published experiences/lessons learned from all technologies implemented by end of 2016 Centre of learning approved and operational in MHS by end of 2016 Guidelines published No. of lessons learned included in policy making at central level

comment.narrative: None None None None

By end of 2016 all lessons learned documented and published Centre of learning approved and operational by end of 2016 At least 2 guidelines for replication published e.g. a) on management models for off-grid applications b) incentive schemes/financial model for RE At least 2 important lessons learned included in policy making at central level

0 0 One guideline for local technicians on technical field assessments to determine potential for off-grid micro-hydro power was published and 700 copies disseminated to provincial and local concerned agencies and TAOs in MHS. Information on several topics and themes of important lessons learned i.e. on micro-hydro power policy, financial support mechanisms, appropriate service delivery models for accessible and affordable RE technologies in poverty stricken areas for off-grid marginalized groups have been gathered. This information will be used in coming year to determine key learnings for inclusion in policies at central level.

title.narrative: FS Catalyzing Sustainability of THs PA System

description.narrative: PIMS: 3825 GEFSEC ID: 3517 Catalyzing Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System

title.narrative: Terminal Review: Catalyzing the Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System (CATSPA) PIMS 3825

description.narrative: PIMS: 3825 GEFSEC ID: 3517 Catalyzing Sustainability of Thailand's Protected Area System.
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Project implementation at Tarutao National Park

description.narrative: capital of a political entity
first-order administrative division
second-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
To overcome barriers to effective management and sustained financing of Thailands protected area system.

1. Policy guidelines and rules enable successful implementation of effective management plans, designing new revenue mechanisms, and improving co-management efforts, particularly with communities and local government.

comment.narrative: Regulations and policies exist but are not clear enough, or enforced properly. Gaps in specific regulations may be hindering PA achievement.
New policy guidelines, and / or new policies, in place to facilitate PA management planning, budgets, finance and co-management.

1) Recommendations on the PA system plan and the policy brief on innovation to make Thailand's protected areas more valuable have been finalized. A high-level consultation platform will be organized by Q3/2015.
2) The 5-year integration plan has been completed; the national park management master plan has been revised by updating some information related to marine national parks (emerging MPA reform issue)
3) The report on preparation of a National Protected Area System Plan sourcebook is being translated prior to use in various settings for discussion on the following issues: proposed PA categories and zones within PAs; PA governance; relations with local and resident communities, (including integration with surrounding land use; the various policies that may need modification to fit within DNP practices; the numerous potential funding mechanisms with a view to selecting those that are most likely succeed; how to generate the many benefits to protected areas; and how to build broader support from multiple stakeholders; and how to build the institutional and staff capacities to implement the improved management of Thailand's PAs.

description.narrative: 2. Formal DNP management and financial effectiveness capacity programs in place.

comment.narrative: Limited formal capacity programs or materials.
Specific programs and materials in place.

The trainings and capacity building workshops organised under the project remains piecemeal and has not been systematically integrated into the DNP system yet. The trainings/ capacity buildings have been designed around the key themes of CATSPA, including sustainable financing, financial scorecards, Management Effectiveness for PA: tools and approaches, the economics of biodiversity and ecosystem conservation, communication for conservation, as well as SMART patrolling. The two core curricular drafted last year have not yet been rolling out, due to the lack of engagement with the core groups of the Effectiveness Unit and the Training Division of DNP. The rapid assessment on training need assessment has been done, and it will inform the development of Marine Protected Areas Capacity Building module, to support DNPs in the reform of the marine protected area management. The consultations with the Training Division, The Recreation Division, as well as the superintendents of the marine protected areas have been undertaken twice, and the outline of the module has been developed.

description.narrative: 3. Completed objective-driven PA management plans and budgets provide clarity on financial need / gap.

comment.narrative: Less than 50% of PAs have management plans. Currently PA or system financial gap is not clear as not all PAs have management plans and DNP budgeting system is based on rough estimates and historical norms.
100% of project demonstration PAs and a growing number of PAs system wide have management plans and budgets (target is 65% by end of project).

80% of project demonstration sites have management plans.
Management Plans are under development for Mae Wong NP and Klong Lan NP. The latter will be integrated into the Thung Yai-Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary World Heritage Site for UNESCO submission.
As noted previously, management plans are in place for Doi Inthanon NP, Eastern Forest Complex, Tarutao (embedded in the Andaman Sea Management Plan) and Huay Kha Kheng WS.

description.narrative: 4. Improvements in DNP budget allocations, and increased non-government PA revenues and sources reduce financial gaps.

comment.narrative: Approximately 75% of non-salary PA system financing is government budget and 25% is tourism. No other significant sources exist.
Additional revenue sources contribute an additional 10% to 5 project PA demonstration sites and PA system plans in place to target a 10% increase across system.

There is no increase in the PA revenues yet. However, the Doi Inthanon Conservation Trust Fund has been launched with strong partnership with the private sector and looks set to that the park will gain additional source of funding supporting their management. Further revenue schemes have been studied with recommendations provided by a consultant for the potential for launching a scheme for a special car license plate with the Depart of Land Transport to support Thai PAs, and for proposals to enhance funding for MPAs, through the introduction of the conservation car plates.

description.narrative: 5. Co-management approaches mainstreamed and effective.

comment.narrative: Co-management approaches between PA (such as Complex) and with communities and other stakeholders (PAC) are relatively new, poorly understood, and underutilized. UNDP Financial Scorecard Total Score = 34%

Complex management plan and budget analysis reveals value of Complex approach. PACs are fully functioning and contributing to management in 5 project demonstration PAs. UNDP Financial Scorecard Total Score = 55%

A final draft of Eastern forest Complex management plan was developed and is being adapted through a newly established EFCom Protected Areas Advisory Committee (PAC)'s.The positive experience with the creation of the Doi Inthanon National Park Business Plan is also being studied for application at EFCOM and Tarutao. PACs in the demonstration sites are all functional and contributing to management. The 2014 UNDP Financial Scorecard score is 31.36%. (The baseline UNDP financial scorecard score was 33.90%)

description.narrative: Improved governance supports enabling environment for long term PA system sustainability.
1.1 5-year integrated national PA system management plan and financial strategy endorsed.

comment.narrative: Currently PA or system financial gap is not clear as not all PAs have management plans and DNP budgeting system is based on rough estimates and historical norms. Formal, bottom-up, financing strategies do not exist.

A financial gap analysis reveals true financial needs, or gaps, for the 5 project pilot PAs and the PA system. The System and 5 PAs have financing strategies. Approach is being rolled out to full PA system.

The final 5-years National Parks Management Plan was refined and updated, in particular relating to marine national parks.
The financial gap and needs assessment has not yet been completed for the PA system. Nevertheless, the business plan for Doi Inthanon NP has been under development but faces difficulty on getting actual expenditure of each government agency in relate to key conservation activities they provided for the park annually.

description.narrative: 1.2 Policies strengthening role of PA Advisory Committees and community participation in PA management is in place.

comment.narrative: Limited guidance or training material exists to promote collaboration with Local government or PA committees.
Policy is strengthened and guidance materials exist.

No result on policies being strengthened nor guidance materials in place yet. The project has reached the level that it managed to form the Eastern Forest Complex (8 PAs) Protected Areas Advisory Committee (PAC) with 34 members consisting of the Foundation to Protect the Forests in the 5 Eastern Province, under the royal patronage, the deputy-chairman of Chantaburi Province;s Chamber of Commerce, the Mayor of Rayong, the Chief Executive of the Chantaburi Provincial Administrative Organization, the East Water Company, the Mab Ta put Industrial estate, Regional Water Authority, head of sub-districts etc. The facilitation, the coordination, and the mechanism to run the EFCOM PAC forms the foundation of the policy recommendations and guidance materials towards the development of complex-level PAC. .

description.narrative: 1.3 Effective M&E and knowledge-based data management system is in place to assess progress and to inform policy decisions

comment.narrative: Actual management and cost performance is not tracked. No formal M&E system looking at total effectiveness of performance exists. Adaptive management is not utilized.
DNP has M&E program (utilizing METT and UNDP Scorecard or similar) and is evaluating PAs, starting with 5 project PAs. Adaptive management measures and processes are in place.

The 2014 METT assessment in the 5 demonstration sites has been taken in September 2014.
Later on, the METT is replicated for Krang Kra Chan Complex (the proposing World Heritage Site) to assess management effectiveness.

description.narrative: Institutional and individual capacities enhanced.
2.1 Effectiveness Unit in place to support project and institutionalized for long-term role in DNP.

comment.narrative: No such integration body within DNP supporting complex management approach

An Effectiveness Unit is in place to support project and is considered for long term role within DNP e.g. being able to generate non-budgetary revenue, complex management approach and PA co-management effectively demonstrated.

The Effective Unit or Institution of Innovation Protected Areas and National Parks is in place. And the new Marine National Parks Section establishment will be a potential unit for CATSPA capacity building, including for competence in developing additional financing and implementing effective management. However, the EFCom's project implementation, such as SMART Program and EFcom's PAC will be showcase for complex management regarding internal practice and external support.

description.narrative: 2.2 Capacity Building Programs on Effective PA Management and Financial Planning Developed for DNP staff as well as partners; and Institutionalised within DNP and partners

comment.narrative: No such formal training or capacity building materials or curriculum exists.
Training materials and curriculum developed. Training completed for key management at pilot PA sites.
Capacity building programs on effective PA management and financial planning. Training materials and curriculum have been developed for system and site levels.

description.narrative: 2.3 Capacity building programs on effective PA management and financial planning developed and institutionalized within DNP and implemented at 5 PA demonstration sites.

comment.narrative: No such formal training or capacity building materials or curriculum exists

Training materials and curriculum developed. Training completed for key management and 5 demonstration PA sites. An Effectiveness Unit is in place to support project and is considered for long term role within DNP. UNDP Capacity scorecard performance increases 25% over baseline year.

A series of training activities have been developed on METT (with 200 participants), sustainable financing (with 80 participants) , business plans (with 70 participants), communication for conservation (with 80 participants), and SMART patrolling (with 250 participants) completed.

description.narrative: Revenue generation mechanisms and management approaches are assessed and tested at 5 PA demonstration sites leading to increased funding levels of the PA system.
3.1 New PA Integrated Management Planning Framework including tools and methods in place and implemented at the pilot units (Outputs 2.1 + 2.2 in Prodoc)

comment.narrative: Basic management plan templates exist. Most plans contain few specific requirements (actions) against clear objectives.

Each of the 5 project PA sites and 1 Eastern Forest Complex has complete, functional management plans. Site level activity plans developed and implemented in line with METT baseline result and management plan. A Clear and consistent PA management framework exists for the PA system. METT score increased by 10% at midterm & by 20% at the end.
Capacity building, including sustainable financing, leads to more effective PA management. (METT scores increased by 20% over baseline for each of 5 demonstration PAs).

Management Plans for Doi inthanon NP, Tarutao NP (combined with the Andaman Sea Management Plan), Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary (combined with Thung Yai-Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary World Heritage management plan) have been completed and are being implementing in the sites. The Eastern Forest Complex management plan has been completed and will soon be used for EFCom PAC's supporting plan and a business plan. Only at 2 project PA sites, the Mae Wong NP and Klong Lan NP are management plans yet to be completed.
The result of 2014 METT score are in this following;
HKK: 2009-63/2014-73= +10
KL:2009-59/2014-83=+24
DI: 2009-77/2014-74=-3
KC-KW: 2009-53/2014-66=+13
TRT: 2009-59/2014-69=+10

description.narrative: 3.2. Financing Mechanism Identified and Implemented at the pilot units

comment.narrative: No feasibility or valuation studies in place. Sustainable financing mechanisms largely absent from PA system. Environmentally economic tools are not systematically applied. Conservation Funds have been looked at in a limited way.

Sustainable financing mechanisms assessed and being pursued within at least 3 PA sites as appropriate. Community, local government and other stakeholders, partnerships leads to better management of well designed and managed funds set-up, sourcing funding from variety of sources (including PA income). Financial Scorecard score increased to 55% at the end of the project

A Conservation Trust Fund was created for Doi Inthanon National Park, with the aim to draw private sector and CSOs supports to PA management. For Doi Inthanon, a Conservation Trust Fund Committee is chaired by the Chairman of the Hotel Association in Chiang Mai Province (wherein Doi Inthanon NP is situated), with the participation from local CSOs and academics. Moreover, the first business plan for PA management has been introduced and developing at this pilot site, based on 10 selected prioritized activities from the Doi Inthanon National Park Management Plan following a participatory process. In Tarutao, the stakeholders' consultations to form the Tarutao Conservation Trust Fund, based on the diving fee and other tourism-related revenue have been conducted. For EFCOM, the financial mechanism will be PES from the Industrial Estate to support the watershed conservation and management of the complex. The valuation of water ecosystem services of EFCOM is being conducted and the engagement with the key private sector in the areas is being developed through the PAC platform. There is no financial mechanism designed for the sub-WEFCOM pilot. The Financial Scorecard was assessed in system level. The site levels and forest complex were tested by the same scorecard as experimentation in September 2014. The 2014 system level's financial score is 29.56%, which decreased from 2012 with gained score at 33.90%. However, this decrease can be explained by a misapplication of the scorecard in the baseline exercise and in fact it was acknowledged that the there was a marked improvement since 2012

description.narrative: 3.3 Co- management Approaches Enhanced: including strengthened PAC at site-level and mechanism/ channels for public engagement in PA management established at site level (Outputs 4.1+4.2 in Prodoc)

comment.narrative: PACs are underutilized and communities and local governments are not engaged in PA management in a consistent or effective manner.
PA system. PACs in particular are utilized more effectively at pilot PA sites. METT score increased by 10% at midterm & by 20% at the end of the project

The Eastern Forest Complex's PAC was recently established by the CATSPA project in close collaboration with Regional Conservation Office No.2 (Sriracha), which has responsibility for 8 protected areas in Eastern Forest Complex. In the meantime, at the western forest complex, and in particular at HKK, Klong Lan and Mae Wong work is progressing on buffer zone management involving PAC members, in order to reduce impacts from encroachment or non-timber product collection. Moreover, CATSPA will organize 4 regions' PACs lesson learned workshops.

description.narrative: 3.4 Regional DNP Offices and PA Staff Capacities Enhanced to Coordinate Management Support and budget allocations across multiple PA in Eastern Complex for improved biodiversity conservation, management effectiveness and cost efficiencies (Output 4.3 in Prodoc)

comment.narrative: Complex plan and budget strategy allows comparison with PA level approach and optimizes management of individual PAs involved.

Promotion of Regional / complex management system leads to better management of PAs in Eastern Forest Complex (measured by METT scores of 8 demonstration PA sites within EFCOM). METT score increased by 10% at midterm & by 20% at the end of the project

Better management of Eastern Forest Complex was introduced by approaching Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) Patrol for the whole complex and the Corridor management between Khao Ang Rue Nai Wildlife Sanctuary and Khao Cha Mao National Park. EFCom's SMART Patrol is initiative approach as the complex patrolling system as well as corridor management.

description.narrative: New models of PA management support effective management of the System.
4.1 Communication Strategy and Materials developed for partnership engagement and advocacy

comment.narrative: Communication is not well integrated in PA system management
Communication is strategically planned, integrated in PA managemen and effectively support partnership engagement and advocacy

Activities conducted under CATSPA have been shared on social media and CATSPA blog (in Thai) and Facebook. Key issues advocated by CATSPA e.g. SMART Patrol (Territorial and Marine), Conservation Trust Funds, have been disseminated through social media.
A major publication Parks for LifeWhy We Love our National Parks has been prepared, stressing the values and importance of Thai protected areas in an attractive and easily accessible format for a wide general public readership.

description.narrative: 4.2 Lessons-learned Captured into Mangement Models for Replication and Policy Decision

comment.narrative: No systematic management of knowledge, policy decision is mostly not linked to study/research or lesson-learned
Various forms of lesson-learned, technical study is easily accessible, policy decision correlates with available knowledge
The knowledge management including best practices and lesson learned has been planned to collect and synthesis systematically by a contracted communication consultant.

description.narrative: 4.3. Regional DNP offices and PA staff capacities enhanced to coordinate management support and budget allocations across multiple PAs in WEFCOM for improved cost efficiencies

comment.narrative: Complex plan and budget strategy allows comparison with PA level approach and optimizes management of individual PAs involved.
Promotion of Regional / complex management system leads to better management of PAs in Western Forest Complex (measured by METT scores of two demonstration PA sites within WEFCOM)

description.narrative: Integrated community-based forest and catchment management through an ecosystem service approach (CBFCM)

title.narrative: PIMS 4033 THA Community based forest mgt FSP DOA 15Feb2012
Mid-Term Review on Inegrated Community-Based Forest and Catchment Management through an Ecosystem Service Approach

description.narrative: Integrated community-based forest and catchment management through an ecosystem service approach (CBFCM)
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration

To create an enabling policy and institutional environment for scaling-up of integrated community-based forest and catchment management (CBFCM) practices through harnessing of innovative financing mechanisms in Thailand
[no indicators]
Strengthened policy environment and systemic capacities to promote sustainable community-based forest and catchment management through PES and biocarbon financing mechanisms
1.1 Number of national policies and plans (identified) that incorporate PES and biocarbon financing mechanism in support of CBFCM.

comment.narrative: Forestry and catchment management policies and legal instruments currently have limited inclusion of CBFCM National/ Regional and Provincial Plans do not include provisions for CBFCM or PES / biocarbon financing.

Natural Resources and Environmental Policies and Plans adapt in implementation of CBFCM utilizing PES and biocarbon financing mechanisms as a mechanism for catchment and forest conservation and management

Key policy and legal frameworks related to PES schemes and bio-carbon were reviewed and recommendations drafted on the priority entry points, including the Environmental Quality Promotion Action Plan (2017-2021). The draft is being reviewed by the project technical advisory team and will be put for a wider public consultation in the next policy dialogue, scheduled in November 2015. The first policy dialogue with key agencies working on PES and bio-carbon under the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) was organised and chaired by the Deputy Director General of the Pollution Control Department. There were representatives from the Department of Marine and Coastal Resource (DMCR), Department of Water Resources (DWR), Royal Forest Department (RFD), Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation (DNP), Office of Natural Resources and Environmental Policy and Planning (ONEP), Office of the Permanent Secretary (OPS), and Biodiversity - Based Economy Development Office (BEDO). The representatives shared the constraints and opportunities they see in piloting the Payment for Ecosystem Services in their different context. The meeting came to a resolution that, there needs to be concrete recommendations on the practical implementation of PES in Thailand in three key aspects: (1) enabling policy and legal frameworks, especially with regards to the establishment of a PES trust fund in each locality to be an operating mechanism; (2) engagement with communities to prepare their capacities and readiness; (3) policy incentives for the private sector to support PES schemes.

description.narrative: 1.2 Existence of a multi-agency/multi- sectoral mechanism for CBFCM/PES -Biocarbon dialogue, consultation with inclusive participation from all relevant government organizations, CSOa, academia, private sector and CBFCM community networks.

comment.narrative:
Seperated and disorganized data base with limited access
Lack of key agency under MONRE or government agency taking clearly responsibility, control and monitoring in this regards.
Ad-hoc Working Group established under the National Environmental Board on Economic Instrument for forest and catchment management

Ad-hoc working Group has not established under the National Environment Board on Economic Instrument for Forest and Catchment Management yet. However, an informal network of exchanges among seven agencies working on PES and bio-carbon under the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE), consisting of the 7 key agencies participating in the policy dialogue as mentioned above. In the first policy dialogue organised in June 2015, the meeting came up with two options in forming this Ad-hoc working Group: (1) the working group could be part of the newly-established Sub-committee on the Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity (TEEB), coordinated by the Office of Natural Resources and Environmental Policy and Planning (ONEP), and reporting to the National Biodiversity Committee and the National Environment Board; (2) the working group could be under the Bureau of Natural Resources and Environmental Strategy, under the Office of the Permanent Secretary of MONRE. The technical consultant on policy framework is now reviewing the pros and cons of the two options and will present them for consideration in the next policy dialogue.

description.narrative: 1.3 Institutional capacities strengthened at national (M&E office) and regional levels (4 pilot REO training centres) to implement PES and biocarbon financing schemed in support of CBFCM

comment.narrative: Limited knowledge and understanding in PES and Biocarbon mechanism and measures
At least 4 REOs can develop mechanisms in applying PES into pratical CBFCM and natural resource management

description.narrative: 1.4 Existence of an active national CBFCM data base (that includes relevant information such as natural resource consumptions rates/patterns, biodiversity levels, PES & biocarbon data) generated through baseline studies and participatory M & E and identification of best practice.

comment.narrative: Currently no such database exist in Thailand
Creation of a National CBFCM PES/biocarbon financing database and mechanisms for information dissemination and knowledge sharing.

The meeting with the seven agencies including DMCR, DWR, RFD, ONEP, OPS and BEDO was conducted on 9 June 2015 in order to discuss about the issues of national CBFCM database. The workshop with the same seven agencies, GIZ and USAID will be conducted on 22 July 2015. Lesson learned and best practice from project which responded by these agencies such as CATSPA of DNP, ECO-BEST of GIZ, LEAF of USAID and CBFCM will be shared and discussed. We will use the information and knowledge sharing form the workshop to create a national CBFCM PES database. The meeting and workshop of seven agencies, GIZ, and other related agencies will be conducted continuously in Q 4/2015 and Q 1/2016 in order to formulate national CBFCM database.

description.narrative: Expanded CBFCM coverage through pilot testing and up-scaling of best practice using PES and biocarbon financing schemes and mechanisms
2.1 Number and Type of PES and biocarbon financing schemes developed and applied (in place) for CBFCM in the 4 pilot sites.

comment.narrative: Currently there are no PES and biocarbon financing strategies and schemes developed and/or applied for CBFCM within the 4 REO pilot site regions.
At least 4 PES and biocarbon financing schemes (1 for each REO region pilot site) are developed and implemented during the project cycle.

There are no PES scheme implemented yet in the 4 pilot sites. Each has established the scope and the scale of PES design and the ecosystem services to be focused, confirmed the baseline information on bio-carbon, biodiversity indicators, and socio-economic data, developing community PES action plans to be matched with the private sector support. Some of the activities in the community PES action plans have been tested run, with the co-financing support from the CSR scheme from the Siam Cement Group. Engagement with key buyers are already developed and strengthened, notably in Mae Sa and Tha Chin. The economic valuation for each pilot site is underway and will be completed in October 2015. The pilot sites expect to fully operationalize the PES scheme by January 2016.

description.narrative: 2.2 Total area of cactchment forests within the 4 pilot catchment basins that benefiting from PES and biocarbon financing schemes

comment.narrative: Current accumulative total of all forest under community management in each of the 4 catchment basin pilot sites. Data collection on total coverage of community managed forests within each catchment basin will need to be undertaken at the start of the project.
Collectively, 15,000 hectares are identified and designated CBFCM forests within the 4 pilot catchment basins.

As the PES scheme in each of the pilot site has not been operationalized, the benefit is still at 0 hectare.
However, the project has established the clear scope of where to assess and monitor the bio-carbon benefit as well as started conducting preparation activities to prepare communities to participate in the PES scheme, including the fire break line, the check dams, and reforestation with monitoring process.

description.narrative: 2.3 Ton of CO2 sequestered and /or avoided emissions within the framework of implemented PES schemes accumulative of all 4 pilot project area catchment basin sites.

comment.narrative: Some work on assessment of forest carbon has been initiated by the RFD and DWNP for Thailands R-PIN application of the World Banks Forest Carbon Partnership Facility (FCPF) Readiness Plan, as well as by independent studies by specialists in various universities. Forest carbon stock assessment will have to be undertaken for the 4 pilot sites.
Existence of knowledge and data base of forest in term of tons of carbon dioxide equivalent sequestration

RECOFTC trained students and communities to use common methodology for carbon absorption measurement in all pilot sites. Bio-carbon measurement in the second year has been measured in early 2015, using participatory monitoring process trained by RECOFT, with engagement from communities and local governments in each area.

description.narrative: 2.4 Keystone species population maintained or enhanced at the 4 pilot sites by reducing threats

comment.narrative: Threats to forests and associated biodiversity continues at demonstration sites
Existence on the keystone speciess threats reduction measures

REOs and RECOFTC made a survey and list of indicator species in Q2/2015. Each site will conduct a workshop with communities to identify species by the end of July 2015 as well as will collect baseline data in September 2015 in Q3/2015

description.narrative: 2.5 5 % Increase in livelihood quality Index (income, health, debt and life security) of households from the baseline

comment.narrative: Some socio-economic data can be obtained by the Community Development Department and the Department of Agricultural Extensions. For the 4 selected pilot sites, data collection must be designed specifically for the purpose of measuring livelihood changes resulting from the project.
5 % increase in livelihood quality of life index in the projects participating communities

The average income of Mae Sa watershed, Tha Chin watershed and Lam Sebai watershed were collected in 2014. The other aspects of livelihood index (health, debt, and life security) has not been finalized yet. Average income in Mae Sa is 60,000 120,000 Baht/household/ Year and debt was 40 %. Income average of Tha Chin is between 10,000 -50,000 Baht/household/ Year; Income average of Lam Sebai is between 5,000 -10,000 Baht/household/Year. For Pha Ngan, as the scoping of ecosystem services has changed from the planned scheme in 2014, due to the lack of receptiveness and participation of the local government in the originally selected areas, the socio-economic data needs to be reworked. The data collection has started in June 2015 and is being finalised in September 2015.

description.narrative: 2.6 Capacities of local authorities and community land users in land use options that enhance PES and to ensure market-based payments from PES and biocarbon financing for improved livelihoods. Environmental Quality of key ES parameters such as water quality, soil nutrient levels, sedimentation.

comment.narrative:
Local capacities in sustainable land use options must be assessed at the beginning of project.
There has been some training provided to local authorities and community land user / community forest & watershed networks on sustainable land use practices through various government and independent projects ES and PES / biocarbon financing.

At least 4 Tambon Administrative Organisations (TAOs) are actively engaged in PES/ biocarbon scheme implementation within their respective communities in support of CBFCM
Overall land use practices in the four pilot catchment basins sufficiently improve.

6 TAOs (1 in Mae Sa, 1 in Lam Sebai, 1 in Koh Phangan and 3 in Tha Chin) in four pilot watersheds are involved in the trainings/ capacity building process organised by the projects, including the hands-on training in bio-carbon assessment and monitoring, community action plan development, and key indicator species. In Mae Sa, although the PES preparation activities are focused in the area under the responsible of 1 TAO, the other 4 TAOs which are in the same catchment have also been engaged to learn about PES and in the capacity building process. In Mae Sa and Tha Chin, the TAOs have been collaborating closely in the development of the community PES action plans, which have the potential to be integrated into the local development plans. The engagement of TAO in Lam Sebai has been improved, due to improved coordination from the project team and the field coordinator at site level. For Pha Ngan, with the change of the focused area, the collaboration with TAO has been improved.

description.narrative: 2.7 Number of national and regional level forums, meetings and documents highlighting best practice and lessons learned in using PES and biocarbon financing for CBFCM.

comment.narrative:
Currently, PES knowledge is in limited (only in acdemic society) and has no communication process intoi watershed and communities levels
PES study is limited and unclear formulation under Thailand context.

At least 4 regional best practice/ lesson learned exchange forum on PES
At least 1 National forum for PES policy strategies and collaboration (declaration of cooperation)

Project Office, Environment Policy and Institute Advisor and Environmental Economic Advisor conducted best practices / lesson learned exchange forum on PES on 22 July 2015. Speakers from Department of National Parks, Wildlife and plant Conservation (DNP) respond for CATSPA project, GIZ respond for ECO-BEST project, USAID respond for LEAF Thailand project and four REOs respond for CBFCM project in four pilot watersheds were invited to share their experience from implementation of PES schemes in local level including start up of project implementation, result, lesson learned, guideline, expansion to practices as well as suggestion for implementation. REOs can apply lesson learned from different project to implement their CBFCM project.

(1) Availability of technical tools developed to mainstream Climate Change into sectoral development planning and budgeting (2) Number of budget requests from sectoral agencies incorporating climate change analysis formulated and submitted to the Bureau of Budget (3) Availability of the common framework for Climate Change analysis at the project and programme level to be integrated as criteria for the Bureau of Budgets consideration for budget appropriation (4) Availability of options for inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangements for climate finance

comment.narrative: (1) 0 (2) 0 (3) Climate Public Expenditures and Institutional Review (CPEIR) completed in 2012 but recommendations not yet developed into a common framework for budget requests and appropriation (4) No inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangement mechanism for climate finance

(1) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis as a tool for climate change planning and budgeting widely communicated to related government agencies for policy advocacy (2) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis submitted to the National Climate Change Committee for views and comments (3) Training Module based on the Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis developed (4) Communication materials related to climate change benefit analysis works undertaken during 2013-15 developed and shared with general public

(1) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis widely communicated to related government agencies through workshops, high level policy forum, social media, and website (2) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis submitted to the National Climate Change Committee in July and further actions on modification and revision were recommended (3) Training Module to be finalized in January 2017 (4) Communication materials i.e. policy briefs, info-graphic, animation etc. developed and shared with general public
